    Mr Speaker: It was with deep sorrow that I, and I am sure hon. Members, heard the news of the death this morning of the hon. Member for Radin Mas, Mr N. Govindasamy.

    I desire, on behalf of the House, to express our sense of the loss we have sustained and our deep sympathy with the family of the hon. Member.

Column: 61

OBITUARY ON THE LATE
HON. MEMBER MR N. GOVINDASAMY


    The Leader of the House (Mr E. W. Barker): Mr Speaker, Sir, the death of Mr N. Govindasamy is a sad start to our proceedings in this Session. The late Mr Govindasamy had not been well for more than a year and Members are aware of that fact. He could have retired last December but he chose to continue to serve his constituents, the Party and the trade unions. He was re-elected with a thumping majority last December. He was sworn in only last Monday and looked forward so much to taking part in our forthcoming debate. What a pity it is that he died this morning in the prime of his life.

    Mr Govindasamy was for long a staunch supporter of the workers and he was their fiery champion in this House. They will miss him and so will we. But knowing Mr Govindasamy. I think he would not want us to adjourn for his sake. The funeral will be held later this afternoon, and those Members who are not due to speak today can attend the funeral.

    May I place on record, Sir, the deep sympathy of Members of this House for his loss. We send our condolences to his bereaved widow and four children.

PRESIDENT'S ADDRESS

DEBATE ON PRESIDENT
(First Day)


    Dr Chiang Hai Ding (Ulu Pandan): Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg to move.

    `That the following Address in reply to the Speech of the President be agreed to:-

    "We, the Parliament of the Republic of Singapore. express our thanks to the President for the Speech which he delivered on behalf of the Government at the opening of the First Session of this Parliament.".'

    The President, in his succinct Address, presented a frank review of the main security, economic and social problems that our country will face in the next few years. He called upon Members of the House, especially those not holding office, to subject every major policy to the closest scrutiny. In this current debate we will miss the late Member for Radin Mas. He was a good friend and his was a cheerful presence in this House. Our thoughts must go to his widow and children. Our thoughts also today must go to the Member for Bukit Merah who lies stricken in hospital. Those of us who are present in the House today will surely heed the call of the President and do our duty. There is much to debate and there will be more to do afterwards.

    In his Address, the President warned Singaporeans against soft options. There have been none. There can be none. Our people have paid their way, all the way. The General Elections of 1 976 demonstrate that Singaporeans are sophisticated; they reject attempts by opposition parties to beguile them with promises of "something for nothing" and "everything for less".

Column: 63



    More Singaporeans today pay income tax than 10 years ago. In 1965 only 4% of the population paid income tax; today 8% do so. And the Singaporean is paying more as well. In 1965 he paid, in the form of income tax, property tax, estate duty, customs and excise, about l0% of his per capita income. Today, the Singaporean pays something closer to 20%. Only in this way has it been possible for Singaporeans to enjoy the quality of life that they do. It is never true that the best things in life are free. We have to work for them. Teachers do not teach our children for free. Doctors do not minister to their patients for free. The Housing and Development Board does not give away apartments. But the productivity of Singaporean and their contribution to the state coffers, make it possible for the state to subsidize, not give for free, education, medical treatment and housing.

    Asian societies lay great store by proper education. Singapore is no exception. At the risk of repeating the obvious, we must guard against "over-education". In another island-economy. Taiwan, there are university graduates who do translations to earn $2.50 a day while carpenters earn $25 a day. Lest Members conclude that this is an Asian phenomenon, the "job crisis" plagues advanced economies as well. In France, universities are described as the "unemployment machine", because half the graduates in recent years cannot find jobs. From America in the northern hemisphere to Australia in the south, the story is the same. We cannot waste our limited resources to educate people who do not meet the needs of our economy. We cannot afford any waste. Of all the countries in the world. Singapore is the most dependent on imported food.

    It is difficult to strike the right balance between higher standards of education so much desired by parents, and the proper type of education to provide their children with a bright future. The Ministry of Education is to be congratulated on correctly emphasising technical education which includes trade and artisan programmes conducted by the Industrial Training Board. I believe,

Column: 64

however, that we must constantly ask ourselves whether we are doing enough to train Singapore professionals, in the banks, the insurance companies, in the fields of personnel management and the like. all of which are vital to the growth of our economy. The work of artisans must be complemented and supported by that of professionals. The strength of our economy is vital to our national resilience.

    As the President noted, the Americans have departed from Vietnam and Thailand. There are new governments in Vietnam, Laos and Cambodia. There is only a residual and miniscule Western presence in Asia. When the Western powers depart, the political institutions they leave behind invariably go by the board. Very, very few of the countries of Asia and Africa, which became independent after World War II, have continued to work the democratic system they inherited; such a system consists of more than one political party and assumes the holding of periodic elections for the people to choose their representatives.

    In Singapore, for the third time, the people have returned the PAP to all the seats in this House. Such a situation is possible in the British Parliament. It has not happened, but that is another story. It almost happened in the then Federation of Malaya. The Tunku's party, campaigning on a platform of Merdeka, won 51 of the 52 contested seats.

    As Members well know, there are variations within the democratic system as described above. Countries in the Commonwealth which adopted the Westminster model will find it difficult to describe as democratic a government in which the chief executive, the President, is not elected, nor the Vice-President nor the Cabinet Ministers. This was the case in America after Watergate. Yet American writers insist that democracy in America exists and indeed flourishes. In that country, for the first 30 years after 1776, there was a loosely-structured one-party system of government. During George Washington's first presidency, all important differences of opinion were expressed within the government party, and the government party

Column: 65

was a party of stability, dedicated to the belief that the first imperative of government in a new nation was to govern and sustain itself. Two pieces of legislation passed in 1798 are of particular interest to new nations. The Aliens and Sedition Acts gave the President the power to order out of the country any alien whom he thought dangerous to the public peace or whom he had reasonable grounds to suspect of plotting against his government. Such aliens did not have recourse to courts of law. The Sedition Act was intended to cope with citizens, or aliens, who too severely criticised the government. It was a serious offence "to publish a false or malicious writing against the Government of the United States, the President or Congress with the purpose of stirring up hatred or resistance against them."

    Mr Speaker, Sir, perhaps we have more to learn from the Americans than merely their science and technology, their management skills and marketing know-how. But let us look ahead. A book on the "Limits to Growth" listed five basic factors that determine growth on this planet: population increase. agricultural production, nonrenewable resource depletion, industrial output and pollution generation. On a global scale, it is argued that unless mankind voluntarily imposes limits to growth. disaster will follow. Opposite viewpoints exist, of course. They argue that conditions in the world will become better and brighter.

    Where is Singapore headed for? We do not even possess two of the factors listed which affect growth - agricultural production and non-renewable resource depletion. None of us would want to generate pollution unnecessarily. Must we inevitably reach our limits to growth? Or can we go on growing indefinitely? As a still emerging LDC (or less developed country), we have no option but to try to grow. Except population-wise. We have very finite resources. Ingenuity and technology can overcome some of the limiting factors. As we run out of land to build houses, we build high-rise apartments; and we reclaim land from the sea. As we run out of roads, we cut

Column: 66

back on cars and we consider travelling underground. As the growth of our entrepot trade slowed down, we industrialised; and we developed banking, insurance and ancillary services to provide a living for our people.

    We have overcome the limitations of our Island by linking our national economy with international and regional economies. The leadership, political and bureaucratic, have undoubtably given some thought to the long-range problems that confront our mini-state. The Ministry of Defence, for example, for which strategic planning is of the utmost importance, is considering National Service for women, as the population growth slows down because Singaporeans accept that "Two is Enough". We have done very well so far in the face of formidable odds. In the short-run, there will be difficulties, but these are not insurmountable.

    But what of the long-term? Let all of us in this House, and others outside who are in the public as well as in the private sectors, give more serious and sustained consideration to our long-term development. The discussion of matters of our economic well-being leads us to what I believe to be the nub of the President's Address, which also received attention in the several Addenda of the Prime Minister, the Minister for Education and the Minister for Culture.

    Singaporeans are told what we must not do as a people. We must "not abandon the cardinal precepts of our long-proven culture systems". We must not seek to model our lives on "Western mores and their contemporary life-styles". Our children will be taught not to adopt the "life-style and values of the West that are alien and pernicious to Singapore society." We are advised to "unequivocably uphold Asian precepts" and to provide our young with the "necessary cultural ballast against the erosion of traditional norms and values".

    But what are these important, desirable things? The Prime Minister tells us what we ought not to be; we cannot be "a simple copying of either China, the Malaysian archipelago, or India, from whence most of

Column: 67

our ancestors came. Nor can we be a copy of Britain." The Minister for Culture enjoins us to develop Singapore's "rich cultural heritage derived from the Malay, Chinese, Indian and western civilisations, and, through their cross-fertilization, to evolve a national identity." The Minister for Education believes that he has an action plan - "to inculcate social discipline and national identity and to imbue in pupils moral and civic values" through the subject called Education For Living. I am happy that we have begun to discuss this crucial subject.

    But we have far to go before Singaporeans possess characteristics that can identify them as Singaporeans, that set us apart from others. For Singapore to thrive, we have to engender in Singaporeans an intense and passionate devotion and love for country. This cannot be legislated into existence.

    As a student, I recall seeing a film based on the life of Chopin, composer, and pianist. He quit his homeland. He won fame. He enjoyed himself. He was the "constant companion" of the leading woman's libber of the age. One day, a Polish thought struck him. He was reminded that his country lay under foreign domination and that his compatriots were suffering. To bring home to Chopin the fact that he seemed to have forgotten his country, his visitor poured into his hands a little bag of earth brought from Poland. And Chopin wept as he saw and felt his native soil. He gave concerts to raise money for his country's struggle for freedom. And in so doing ruined his health and died. It is a romantic story but it is the patriotism that matters.

    I was therefore saddened to hear over RTS the other night that three of our National Service officers (two of them medical doctors and one a university student) called up for National Service had shirked their responsibility. These men have no patriotism. They took all that Singapore can give them. Then they packed up and quit. They had put self above all else. These few are exceptions but they were well-instructed Singaporeans.

Column: 68



    How do we go about inculcating patriotism? We start without some of the advantages enjoyed by other and older nations, such as a historical state with some claims to greatness, the existence of some inspiring monuments, memories of a long, heroic struggle against foreign invaders and colonizers. I do not have the answers. But the answer does not lie in the misbegotten subject Education For Living.

    I believe that our children, in addition to knowing their mother tongue, must also learn the history of the countries whence their ancestors came, why they came, what they had to endure, what factors enabled them to survive, to develop and to prosper, and how they have come to found a nation - Singapore. Indeed, as a matter of deliberate policy, we have to encourage our children to identify with places and events, and especially people in Singapore. Who was Cheang Hong Lim who had a square named after him and who until recently was represented in this House? What of Hoo Ah Kay, popularly known as Whampoa, a name given to an electoral division, which was once eliminated, then resuscitated? Many Members represent constituencies named after people whose lives have meaning, interest and instruction for our young, such as Aljunied, Braddell, Kuo Chuan and Mountbatten. I must not forget MacPherson constituency represented by the Minister for Education.

    When we have a shared and active knowledge of our past as a means to appreciate the contributions of the people who settled here, then we can dream of a common future. When will Singaporeans begin to have such a dream? A dream such as an American freedom-fighter had. Martin Luther King in his most famous speech, made just before he was assassinated, said,

    `I still have a dream. It is a dream deeply rooted in the American dream I have a dream that my four little children will one day live in a nation where they will not be judged by the colour of their skin, but by the content of their character.'

    Mr Speaker, Sir, in the last one dozen years we have begun to build a new Singapore, independent and sovereign. The

Column: 69

physical landscape has changed almost beyond recognition in many parts of our island. However, our children need to possess a common hope for the future, a vision common to them all, a Singapore dream, which will inspire them, create new sensitivities and release their energies to build upon what we have already achieved. Then when our children raise their glasses to a toast Wo Kuo Wan Suay they will be pledging, "My country, will live 10,000 years".

    Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg to move.

    Question proposed.

3.00 p.m.

    Mr J. F. Conceicao (Katong): Mr Speaker, Sir, I rise in support of the Motion of the Member for Ulu Pandan.

    The results of the Elections of 1976 showed that the Government received strong support from the working classes including those who were relatively less well-off, for example, those who lived in one-room flats in HDB premises. The Ministry of Labour report of the labour force survey. 1976, indicated that 27% of employed persons received under $200 a month, while 42% received between $200-$399, and this amounts to nearly 70% of the population of employed persons. And it could not have been but that the bulk of these people and their family connections voted for us. It should therefore be the Government's right aim to continue to devote as much of its resources as possible towards improving the lot of these people.

    During the last elections, some opposition candidates moved hither and thither chattering about building a caring society as though this Government did not care for the people. Included among the goodies many opposition candidates were trying to sell was the offer of subsidised living. Correctly, as the Member for Ulu Pandan has pointed out, the voters refused to buy this. It is not through sentimental concepts that the quality of life of our people is best improved but that our compassion for our people should be the basis of sound, careful, determined planning

Column: 70

and execution of policy to bring about improvements for our people.

    Throughout the years since 1959 through a careful husbanding of our resources, spending has been made possible on improved provisions towards building a better society all round. Whatever the area of Government effort a Member of Parliament may find himself particularly interested in, he can assure himself of significant successes achieved in that particular area of Government activity. For example. I have been particularly interested in educational development and I have tried to make myself a little knowledgeable regarding Government's efforts in this area. There is no doubt that by any criteria. including those applied by foreign education experts. the Government's achievements in education have been impressive.

    The burden of the Education Ministry, in the addendum, is the qualitative improvement of our education provision, which can only be a consequence of the Government's past practical achievements, one of which most people think has been in overcoming the problem of numbers by giving a place to every child in primary school. Certainly this has been one attainment but, in my mind, one of the outstanding achievements has been in the breakthrough, number-wise as well as in terms of the diversification of provisions, in the area of secondary schooling. In 1959, the percentage of persons of the correct age enrolled in primary schools was 88%. In 1975, this percentage rose to over 98%. In 1959, the percentage of persons of correct age enrolled in secondary schools was 19% while in 1975 the number rose to about 50%. More significantly Secondary I enrolments increased from 11.5% in 1959 to nearly 55% in 1975. namely the enrolment in Secondary I rose from about 4.000 to over 30,000. While Primary I enrolment of those persons aged 6 increased by nearly 27% between 1959 and 1975, the enrolment in Secondary I of persons aged 12 increased by more than 7 1/2 times. As secondary education was closely related to better job opportunities, does this not show how practically and realistically the Government cared?

Column: 71



    In 1959, the then Finance Minister who is now Deputy Prime Minister showed with what dismay he viewed the problem of providing education for the increasing number of children having to attend school. The Minister said [Hansard, Vol. 11, col. 785, 25.11.59]:

    `The large number of babies born every year may be a welcome testimony to the virility of the population but it Sets in Store problems of nightmarish proportions for the Finance Minister.'

    Does this not display anxiety? Does this not show that the Government cared in such a way that the Government showed itself financewise firmly committed to educational development? From 1960 to the present year, allocations for education have shown continuous growth. In 1964, despite a fall in the GNP and also a fall in Government recurrent expenditure generally. educational recurrent expenditure went up 9.2% over the previous year's expenditure.

    Other MPs who are interested in other fields may well record the same sense of responsible concern in other areas.

    But apart from concern being expressed in policy action there are indications, throughout the various addenda of more specifically humane considerations - for example: the concern for industrial safety and health expressed in the very concrete steps that are being planned, including the establishment of an occupational safety and health institute; the thinking manifested in the intention of the Ministry of Health to lay greater emphasis on primary health care, preventive medicine and health education; the sympathy for the old expressed in the establishment of the home nursing foundation. Such measures illustrate a practical concern for people, not a sentimental indulgence in vague expressions of care.

    Indeed, Sir, going through the various addenda to the President's Address, one is struck by the very tangible, material, concrete, rational, hard-headed proposals outlined. Although the addenda relate to general policy declarations, we can read

Column: 72

about percentage growth, extension of national service to women, National Wages Council, the expansion of the domestic telephone network, and so on, including even the trite (but still particular) intention of the Ministry of Science to launch a follow-up to the Science and Industry Quiz.

    However, when we stray to some areas covered by the addenda on the Education and Culture Ministries, we find that we have wandered into a rather misty, if not actually foggy environment, where the landscape has become diffused, and the configuration a little blurred.

    The Ministry of Culture is concerned with evolving a national cultural identity and will organise activities to promote a better appreciation of our cultural heritage, and in the process protect our young against the erosion of traditional norms and values. Later on, Sir, when we come to the debate in the Committee of Supply, I hope we will hear from the Minister concerned, the specifics of such action as his Ministry intends to take. I remember, Sir, a bitter complaint from an official of the People's Association about what a budget official once asked. It seems that at a meeting with budget officials, the People's Association representative stated that his agency was involved in efforts to build a sense of national identity, and inculcate the right values in our people. The Treasury official was very impressed and asked the PA official how many good Singaporeans the PA had produced. Perhaps the question was a heartless one, but it indicates the difficulty of a hard assessment of this thing called "values".

    Despite this difficulty, Sir, we find the addendum on the Ministry of Education declaring that great pains will be taken to ensure that pupils imbibe the tried, not simply tried and tested Asian cultural and moral values but the tried and tested Asian cultural and moral values. I shall ask the Ministry to tell me since they appear to have already identified the tried and tested virtues, what these virtues are and how they propose to teach these values.

Column: 73



    Mr Speaker, Sir, one of the pillars of development in our society has been the success in our family planning policy. With an appropriate reduction in the growth of our population we are now able to plan for measures more effectively, measures that it would have been difficult to envisage as possible even 10 years ago, because money that we will now be able to spend on these measures would otherwise have gone on the spending of less and less money on more and more people. Yet in some ways family planning would have gone against the traditional grain. Family planning is a modern idea in the sense it is administered today. Traditional agrarian cultures (whether east or west) would extol the virtues of a large family.

    To show that values may be difficult to determine. and undergo change, let us just observe what they are doing to Confucius in China today. They are calling him sage of the reactionary classes. Yesterday's Confucian stipulation of three cardinal guides, namely, that subject must be guided by sovereign, son must be guided by father, and wife must be guided by husband, has been described in Mao-thought as the authorities - political, clan and masculine authorities - that are the embodiment of the whole feudal system and ideology and the thick ropes binding the Chinese people, particularly the peasants. It is interesting to note how the Chinese today reject male chauvinism - a point that this all-male house might find worthy to note. In China again, today, the ideologues have attributed a highly sinister political motivation to the Confucian aim of Yu chiao wu /ui which was traditionally taken to mean giving education irrespective of class barriers. This has been described by Chinese communists as humbug, as they think that Confucian modes were designed to make the masses pliable instruments in the hands of the rulers.

    Even when you think of literature as containing lessons, in a spate of criticism of Water Margin in 1975, Chairman Mao was noted as having pointed out that the merit of the book Water Margin lay precisely in the portrayal of capitulation - meaning, of

Column: 74

course, capitulation to the feudal principles; and Mao pointed out that Water Margin served as a teaching material by negative example to help all the people recognise capitulationism. Even Ge un suo neng, an lao fen p'ei will change if the communist millennium is attained.

    When we talk of values, therefore, let us talk of values - for what purposes, just like the Chinese in China today discuss their values in terms of the political aims and in terms of the practical condition of their society today. What is the kind of society we want to develop? Let us start with this idea that we want a society that is reasonably secure and properly educated with reasonable prospects for economic advancement. We therefore stress economic development, dissemination of modern techniques and rational attitudes with full exploitation of the mass media to disseminate those attitudes and to change traditional outlooks that stand in the path of development and in the path of modernisation. We realise the importance of industrialisation and urbanisation, the establishment of a management elite, bureaucratisation that is necessary, the espousal of analytic intelligent modes of social appraisal, the inculcation of a sense of common destiny and belonging and the inculcation of humane and loyal regard as between one citizen and another. I do not think that this is an unreasonable statement of social aim for Singapore. But whether people agree with me totally, or disagree with what I have said partially or even totally, there must be a social aim underlying the kind of values we want to give our people.

    This may be illustrated by the experience of Japan. When the Japanese experienced the emergence of a modern constitutional government and the build-up of their administrative system of a modern unified state, the education system underwent changes. There emerged a two-tier structure of education in which elementary education confined to basic literacy and numeracy attached importance to ethics, moral education to foster Japanese citizens who would acquire the ethics of the family system

Column: 75

and pledge allegiance to the family and the community. At the apex, the educational system positively adopted the modern civilisation of the West, emphasised science, developed an elite to engage in the operation of modern technology and managerial organisation.

    Let me emphasise. Sir, that in their basic education, the Japanese emphasised the importance of fostering Japanese values. In our case instead of stressing Singapore references, as the Member for Ulu Pandan has recommended, we are thinking of Asian values.

    `I have very serious doubts as to whether such a thing as "Asian values" really exist... It may exist as an image but it has no reality. If it has any meaning at all it is merely a convenient way of describing the heterogeneous, conflicting and complex network of beliefs, prejudices and values developed in the countries which for geographical purposes have been grouped as being in Asia'.

    Sir, these are not my words, although I agree fully with them. These words constitute a quotation from a recent publication. Asian Values and Modernisation. page 95, and belong to our own Foreign Minister who goes on later to emphasise that.

    `there is much in traditional values (whether Asian, Western or African) which are far more modern and more likely to give impetus to modernisation than some contemporary values.'

    The point I am making is that we have to ponder and select, and the basis is what I have already referred to - relevance to Singapore's development and her people's harmonious living.

    However, a further point has to be made. It is not only the children in our schools who need to be educated to values that will contribute to Singapore's development and the harmonious living of our people. The adult citizens of our Republic have to be continually exposed to the play of influences that will result in further improvement to our society.
